results.summary: Knife crime has dropped by 25% in the West Midlands, according to new police figures.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/01222fe9-96e8-174f-9b53-2b16875935a3"><paragraph role="introduction">Knife crime in the West Midlands has fallen by a quarter, according to new police figures.</paragraph><paragraph>West Midlands Police said knife-related offences had fallen from 2,995 between April 2011 and 2012 to 2,237 during the following 12 month period.</paragraph><paragraph>It had received £1m from the government over two years to tackle the problem.</paragraph><paragraph>The force said incidents like the fatal stabbings of two Big Issue sellers and teenager Christina Edkins in Birmingham were "mercifully rare".</paragraph><paragraph>Assistant Chief Constable Sharon Rowe described the figures as "promising."</paragraph><paragraph>She said the force had dealt with a number of "terrible" knife crimes in the past few months including the fatal stabbing of Christina on a bus in in March but she said these incidents should be "viewed in context".</paragraph><paragraph>"Crimes involving knives are down massively in the last decade and are now mercifully rare," she said. </paragraph><paragraph>"It's easy to read about such terrible crimes and believe crime is on the up but in reality crime is down and down considerably."</paragraph><crosshead>'Worrying'</crosshead><paragraph>The force had received £1m from the government's Communities Against Gun, Gangs and Knives project over two years but funding finished last month.</paragraph><paragraph>Birmingham charity Brap, which is working to tackle knife crime in the city, received £10,000 from that fund which it used to help young people who had been in trouble with the police.</paragraph><paragraph>Joy Warmington, from Brap, said the Home Office had not indicated whether it would receive any more funding.</paragraph><paragraph>"It has left us with a challenge because the scheme has got momentum and trust and it's going to be hard to pull back from it," she said. </paragraph><paragraph>"If we're not offering young people alternatives, we're not giving them a way of getting out of the problems of crime and given that youth funding is being cut too, it is worrying." </paragraph><paragraph>The Home Office said although police figures showed knife crime was down it was not complacent.</paragraph><paragraph>West Midlands Police figures showed that overall crime had fallen by 11% from April 2012 to March 2013 compared to the previous 12-month period with reductions in business crime, burglary and robbery.</paragraph></body>
